Answer THREE questions. Do not turn over the page until told that you may do so. 0102 2 LAST PAGE 1. ‘Propositional knowledge does not reduce to the conjunction of other conditions.’ Discuss. 2. EITHER (a) What is the difference, if any, between projectible and non-projectible predicates? OR (b) Defend what you take to be the best solution to the problem of induction. 3. ‘The problem of external-world scepticism has no acceptable solution.’ Discuss. 4. Can there be such a thing as knowledge by testimony alone? 5. Critically discuss at least two approaches to a priori knowledge. 6. ‘Veridical perception and hallucination have nothing in common.’ Discuss. 7. Does knowledge have a foundation? 8. Why, if at all, is mathematical knowledge problematic? 9. ‘Ideally rational degrees of belief should be probabilistically coherent. They should also be conditioned on new input.’ Discuss. 10. Is there any good reason to believe that possible worlds exist? 11. ‘Necessarily: for any things x, y and z there exists something Σ which is their mereological sum.’ Discuss. 12. Can causation be analysed in other terms? 13. In what, if anything, does the flow of time consist? 14. Can we make sense of resemblance without appeal to universals? 15. ‘Existence is a property like any other.’ Discuss. 16. What are the strengths and weaknesses of deflationism about truth? 17. Will you ever be a corpse? 18. What is the difference, if any, between primary and secondary qualities? 19. How, if at all, do ordinary physical objects persist?
